name: Mathematics for Engineering and Technology I

timeGuidelines.description: The standard instructional time for this course is 75 hours.

description: This course enables the student to apply the basic knowledge of algebra and introductory calculus to resolve applied scientific and technological problems. Applications include linear motion, areas under curves, and volumes of revolution.

courseDescription.overview: This course enables the student to apply the basic knowledge of algebra and introductory calculus to resolve applied scientific and technological problems. Applications include linear motion, areas under curves, and volumes of revolution.
courseDescription.timeGuidelines: The standard instructional time for this course is 75 hours.

classTimes: Monday 3.00pm -3.50pm; Wednesday 8.00 am- 9.50 am; Friday 2.00 pm – 3.50 pm

learningOutcomes.title: Solve for the limiting value of a function using the properties of limits
objectives: Determine the continuity of a function
Evaluate simple limits algebraically using limit notation
Evaluate simple limits graphically
Evaluate indeterminate limits by specialized techniques

learningOutcomes.title: Determine the derivative using first principles
objectives: Determine the average rate of change of a function
Determine the instantaneous rate of change of a function from first principles
Calculate the slope of a tangent to a curve
Determine derivatives by employing the definition of the derivative

learningOutcomes.title: Differentiate algebraic functions using fundamental formulas
objectives: Determine derivatives using the power rule
Determine derivatives using the product and quotient rules
Determine derivatives using the chain rule
Determine successive (i.e. higher order) derivatives
Determine derivatives by applying the technique of implicit differentiation

learningOutcomes.title: Solve problems involving applications of the derivative
objectives: Determine the equation of a tangent or a normal line to a curve
Solve linear motion application problems
Solve related rates problems
Graph algebraic equations employing derivative and limit curve-sketching techniques
Solve maximum and minimum application problems
Solve linear differential approximation problems including error calculations with appropriate significant digits

learningOutcomes.title: Determine the indefinite, definite, and particular integrals of algebraic functions
objectives: Determine antiderivatives and integrals of algebraic functions
Evaluate the constant of integration
Determine the particular equation of a curve given a point on the curve
Evaluate the definite integral
Approximate a definite integral using the trapezoidal rule

learningOutcomes.title: Solve problems involving applications of integration
objectives: Solve applied integration problems involving displacement, velocity and acceleration
Calculate areas under and between curves employing integration techniques
Determine the volume obtained by rotating an area around an axis

assessment.description: Component Weight: Online Quiz/Assignment (on Pearsonmylab) 10%, 2 Tests (10% each) 20%, Mid-term Exam 30%, Final Exam 40%, Total 100%

schedule.topic: Solve for the limiting value of a function using the properties of limits
Determine the derivative using first principles
Differentiate polynomials including higher derivatives, tangents, and normal lines
Solve linear and curvilinear motion problems; Solve related rates problems
Graph polynomial equations employing derivative curve-sketching techniques; Solve max & min problems
Application problems; Differentials and linear approximation
Trapezoidal Rule; Area under the curve

calculator.requirement: Simple scientific calculator is required. (No smart devices, no graphing calculators).
calculator.restrictions: Students are NOT PERMITTED to use any type of graphing calculators during tests and exams. Simple scientific calculator is required.

attendance.policy: Attendance will be taken during every class. You are expected to attend ALL classes. Please be informed that if you miss any class, you are responsible for the missed content, not the instructor. You may refer to the course schedule or see notes taken by your colleagues. Sending email to the instructor when you are absent will not be an acceptable means of catching up on missed classes. Being absent without catching up on the missed content may have a significant effect on your grades.

missedEvaluation.policy: Test rewrite is NOT automatic. There will be NO REWRITE of assessments. Students are required to provide prior notice BEFORE THE TEST, not after, else, ZERO mark will apply. Missed lab, test or exam will attract ZERO MARK. For health-related issues, you will be required to submit SAIT's physician statement to the instructor before limited options of a re-write can be considered. Any other claim must be substantiated by an appropriate document, otherwise zero mark will apply.

homework.policy: A key factor to your success in this course is making sure that you do your assigned homework problems. This is in addition to regular class attendance and active participation.

grades.policy: Grades will be turned in within 5 business days of assessment.

classExpectations: Learners are strongly encouraged to use SAIT email address ONLY for all correspondence. Non-compliance will attract 'no response'.

Every grade after each assessment stands. There will be NO BOOSTING OF GRADES with any extra assignment/exercise. All learners will have ONE equal opportunity on assessments. Hence, learners are encouraged to do all homework as suggested and start prep. early enough before each assessment.
Every student is encouraged to check SAIT emails regularly, likewise Brightspace for any announcement.

To be successful in this course, 'regular attendance/active class participation/doing homework' is strongly recommended and highly encouraged. Respectful behavior is expected at all levels in this class.
Regular practice is advised as this is a major factor that will contribute to your success in this course.
Please explore all the documents, class worksheets, etc, posted on Brightspace to your advantage.

Where applicable, answers alone are not sufficient. Show enough of your method so as to clearly indicate HOW you arrived at your answer. Marks will be given only for work that is CLEARLY shown and LEGIBLY presented.
Students are NOT PERMITTED to use any type of graphing calculators during tests and exams. Simple scientific calculator is required.
During assessments, cell phones must be turned off and put in bags, where bags are placed below the white board.
Smart watches and non-religious hat are NOT permitted during assessments.
